Expectation1: Ensuring financial stability for the family
Situation1: The child has been promised a Nintendo, and the step-parent should purchase it
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A nervous new client steps inside, glancing around the salon for direction.
Story:
I was sweeping up hair clippings when my phone buzzed with a text from my partner: “Don’t forget, you promised Jamie the Nintendo today.” My stomach tightened. Jamie had been counting down the days, and I’d seen the hope in his eyes every morning. I wanted to keep my word, to show him he could trust me, that I was really part of this family. But the cost of the console would mean dipping into the rent money, and I’d been picking up extra shifts just to keep us afloat.

Just then, the bell above the salon door jingled. A woman stepped in, clutching her purse, her eyes darting nervously. I recognized the look—first-time jitters. My boss always said, “First impressions matter. Make them feel at home.” I was supposed to greet her warmly, offer tea, and put her at ease. But my mind was racing with numbers and promises, torn between the anxious client in front of me and the anxious child waiting at home. I forced a smile, feeling the weight of both worlds pressing in, unsure which expectation I could afford to let down.
